articleContent.title: Winter Wonderland
articleContent.body: Santa's Fantastical is an immersive holiday experience, featuring multiple interactive touchpoints and games. Experience everything from soaring auroras to virtual snowball fights.

articleContent.title: Depth Sensing
articleContent.body: These experiences are built in Unity, and driven by Intel RealSense depth cameras. These cameras were used to track the silhouettes of guests and objects, translating the real world into particle systems and virtual physics objects.

articleContent.title: Yeti Tracks
articleContent.body: Tracking small, white snowballs against a snowy landscape presented some unique challenges, especially when you add high velocity into the mix. Through multiple iterations of different tracking techniques, the experience achieved accuracy and reliability for over a dozen simultaneous guests.

articleContent.title: Particles Galore
articleContent.body: Unity's visual effect graph drives the realtime effects in these experiences, allowing for beautiful visual landscapes of millions of particles with relatively low overhead.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: I was the lead developer, handling the programming and realtime visual effects for the aurora, slide, and snowball fight experiences. I also worked on-site during testing and installation to ensure things got up and running smoothly.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: Unity, Intel RealSense, OpenCV

articleContent.title: An Interactive Museum Exhibit
articleContent.body: Word Play was an interactive installation spanning a 40ft section of wall at the Museum of Design Atlanta. Visitors who walked through the center of the room were rewarded with the chance to fling ribbons of text across the gallery walls, streams of text acting as extensions of their hands. When idle, the blue text crawling slowly along the wall added colorful ambiance to the dim gallery.

articleContent.title: Text Me
articleContent.body: Featured in Text Me: How We Live in Language at the Museum of Design Atlanta, this installation was displayed alongside work by Stefan Sagmeister, Milton Glaser and Paula Scher, among others. It occupied an entire wall of a space devoted to interactive and video art, and was a popular point of engagement for kids and adults alike.

articleContent.title: Motion Controlled
articleContent.body: This project was developed in Unity, and a single Microsoft Kinect mounted at the center of the display drove the interactivity. Kinectâ€™s excellent built in skeletal tracking and strong community support made development a breeze, allowing the team to prototype and deliver quickly.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: I served as the lead developer, and handled all of the programming for this project. That included typical Unity scripting, interfacing with the Kinect SDK, building the Unity scene, and making some on-the-fly changes during installation. It was the first time I have had to write code while upside-down on a ladder.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: Unity, Microsoft Kinect

articleContent.title: Material Science
articleContent.body: This proof of concept turns a touch screen interface into a novel tactile experience. Fluid visuals are projected onto an elastic screen material, and vibrant colors bloom under the users fingertips as they sink deeply into the screen surface.

articleContent.title: Touch Design
articleContent.body: This project leverages TouchDesigner's powerful realtime video compositing, as well as plug and play modules for depth sensors and computer vision.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: This was a solo project, I handled everything from design concept to programming and execution.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: TouchDesigner, Intel RealSense

articleContent.title: Credits
articleContent.body: Free HD Stock-Footage and Motion Graphics by CyberWebFX.

articleContent.title: Making Muppets Dance
articleContent.body: I have had the pleasure of working on numerous educational games and activities for Sesame Street - everything from sending Elmo hurtling through space, to helping Oscar the Grouch muck up some tuxedos.

articleContent.title: Web Games for All
articleContent.body: The goal of any Sesame Street game is to provide education and entertainment to all, which means not limiting access based on hardware or platform. All of these games are built for the web, and designed to provide the best experience even on older browsers and devices.

articleContent.title: Endless Engines
articleContent.body: Over the years, technologies and production techniques have changed. These games have been built one a wide variety of platforms to match - numerous custom engines built on Flash, CreateJS, and PixiJS.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: I have been the lead developer on many of these games and the frameworks behind them, including Super Salad Diner, Elmo's World Games, Show Me The Cookies, Pinball Number Count, The Cookie Games, Junk My Jacket, Big Bird's Basketball, Abby's Smoothie Maker, Comfy Cozy Nest, and Breathe Think Do. Additionally, I provided direction and support on several other games and activities.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: CreateJS, PixiJS, Adobe Animate, Springroll, Unity

articleContent.title: Play and Learn
articleContent.body: The Play and Learn Science app is an exploration into the physical phenomena of our world for PBS Kids. It gives kids the opportunity to play with light and shadow, construct water walls, and control the weather with the guidance of classic PBS Kids characters.

articleContent.title: Award Winning
articleContent.body: Beloved by kids, parents, and educators, this app received the prestigious Excellence in Early Learning Digital Media Award from the American Library Association.

articleContent.title: Light and Water
articleContent.body: There is some fun technology underneath the 2D animated surface. Unique shaders simulate 2D shadows and generate metaballs for water. And speaking of water, creating satisfying fluid movement that runs smoothly on low end mobile devices presented it's own challenge.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: I was the lead developer on this project, handling the majority of the programming and scene construction in Unity.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: Unity, Adobe Animate

articleContent.title: Get Rekt!
articleContent.body: Mega Spacehole is a virtual reality arcade game, filled with dozens of blowing things up with your face - no controller needed.

articleContent.title: Early Adopters
articleContent.body: Released in early 2016 for Gear VR, this was developed in the early days of consumer virtual reality. Development kits and beta software were necessities, and this was one of a handful of titles released in the early days of the platform.

articleContent.title: Around the World
articleContent.body: Licensing deals ensured that this game expanded beyond the GearVR, successfully deploying on additional platforms in international markets.

articleContent.title: Role
articleContent.body: I was the developer half of the two man team behind this, working many long nights and weekends to bring this indie game to market.

articleContent.title: Technologies
articleContent.body: Unity, Samsung GearVR

articleContent.title: All the Small Things
articleContent.body: A collection of small projects, demos, and experiments, some of which are linked below. All of these projects were done on the side, for no client in particular, though some were presented to friends and coworkers for fun.

articleContent.title: Powderpuff
articleContent.body: A small generative art toy. Built directly with the 2D Canvas API, this project uses no third party libraries for tweening or rendering.

articleContent.title: Deep Dream
articleContent.body: An experiment applying neural network style transfer to video footage, the goal being to find combinations of style images and video that produced compelling results. As this was my first time working with neural networks of any kind, this used pretrained models and an open source style transfer implementation.

articleContent.title: Spoopy Woods
articleContent.body: A quick game demo, created in collaboration with an artist to test new technologies and workflows. Intended to showcase Spine animation, normal mapping on 2D sprites, and novel level design techniques. Not intended to perform well on low end devices.

articleContent.title: Flavor Mashup
articleContent.body: A silly website to create new and often vile food combinations, accompanied by a (now defunct) Twitter bot. There are many random generators, but this one is mine.
